instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
This plate came dead. After replacing some oxidized components, traditional resistor <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> and I did Rebaling in SMC because of the oxidation. It returned to normal, in the tests the BKL stopped!

Test with another screen - ok
Checked Trails - Ok
F9700 - Ok
<DIODE>D9701</DIODE> - Post-diode p2 .607 - P1 .405 - With and without screen
<DIODE>D9701</DIODE> - P2 12.5V - P1 12.56V

<TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> - 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6 - 12.56V / 3 - 4V
L9008 / L9004 - 3.27V - Both pins

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
"Test with another screen - ok"
What this means, do you get vacklight with other screen???
I suppose not, but is not the correct way to say that!

Post <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM levels; be sure <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> is good.
Do PRAM reset 2-3 times.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Excuse me. The idea was that he had already tested with another screen.

<RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> is good!
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> - 2.9V
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> - 0V (bad sign?)

I had already checked reset PRAM!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> and run wire from <CAPACITOR>C9704</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR>.
If backlight comes on, test the machine few hours; then rebuild original circuit and check again <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: It worked, I have BKL! I will test and come back for feedback.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: Just in case, do PRAM reset again; before rebuild original circuit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Rebuild the circuit, stopped the BKL. I used components from another board.

I noticed that the power button stopped working to turn on. If you try to turn off by pressing, it works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
PCH problems probably.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.
Check all PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
I don't have a pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> when I try <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>!

<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.26V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 1.65v (problem, no?)
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> - 2.5v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.26V

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: Force 100K in place of <RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR>, instead of 1M.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: Does not work with 100k! =/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> still low?
If yes, heat PCH area with quality flux.
May have luck to be caused by accumulated crap underneath PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> is at 3v now. but still without pulse in <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. Also without BKL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Heat reaction may be caused by accumulated crap, or PCH internal issue:
Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> points to PCH problem; seems to be generated only when charger is plugged in.
But you need to confirm signals from SMC toPCH first.

Did you check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> for pulse at same time when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
Be sure to have drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
I tried to heat the PCH, I also put it in the tub to clean! Unsuccessfully!

Exactly, only have the signal <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> with charger. Triggering the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, I don't have a pulse. I'm testing with the battery, the power button and <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> don't turn off the board. So I put the battery in and try to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

I will check SMC signals to PCH, can it be SMC bad?

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> always 3.4v, no drop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
"Exactly, only have the signal <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> with charger"
Do you mean <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is high when you connect the charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: Yes, I have 3.3v with charger and board connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> should drop when SMC detects <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.
If not, try changing SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
BINGO! With different SMC, everything works! I'll try!

Can I leave the <RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR> with 100k?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: You can leave 100K without peoblems.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
thank you my friend!

Saved once more!
